results.title: Boys on film 1: Pool days. The Dead boys club
results.creator_credit: Brian Sloan, Michael Christopher, Mary Weisgerber Meyer and House of Pain Productions
results.brief_description: Two short American films about adolescent homosexual experiences. In “Pool days” (prod/dir: Brian Sloan), a young man begins work at a neighbourhood pool and dormant gay feelings are stirred being around nude, attractive men. In “The Dead Boys Club” (prod: Mary Weisgerber, dir: Michael Christopher) a young man goes to visit his cousin, whose lover has died from AIDS. When the young man puts on the dead man’s shoes he is transported into the disco era of the 1970s where sex and relationships were free of the fear of disease. These two films are light and joyous celebrations of queer life.

results.title: Bosnia at war: we are all neighbours
results.creator_credit: Debbie Christie, Granada Television International and London Weekend Television
results.brief_description: Part of an award winning trilogy which focuses on war from a humanist rather than a political perspective. The conflict in Bosnia-Hercegovina has divided families and friends. The area, once a famous tourist haven has suffered under a terrible war in the ‘90’s. This program looks at two women who have been neighbours for many years; one is Muslim, the other Catholic. Their friendship is under constant strain due to the civil unrest in their village, and yet, though fragile, it continues to endure. Other stories focus on the hardships individuals face during the conflict such as lack of supplies and family seperation.

results.title: Boro's ballet: the making of an Australian ballet 1939-1961
results.creator_credit: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, Jean Wein, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and National Library of Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Boro’s Ballet’ focuses on the life of Edouard Borovansky (1902-1959) and on his dream of establishing an Australian ballet company. Borovansky, a former dancer with the Paris-based Russian Ballet Company Ballet Russes, moved to Melbourne and established a ballet academy and the Borovansky Australian Ballet in 1939. In 1960 Peggy van Praagh, a former dancer and choreographer with the Royal Ballet of London, inherited the company from Borovansky. It was renamed the Australian Ballet Company in 1962. The documentary follows his early struggles to establish a school, and pays tribute to his outstanding dancers. It features rare footage of the company in rehearsal and on stage from the 1940s to 1959. This co-production between Screen Sound Australia (National Film and Sound Archive) and the National Library of Australia comprises rare professional and amateur footage and other materials and memorabilia from their collections.

results.title: Bowling for Columbine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Moore, Jim Czarnecki, Kathleen Glynn, Dog Eat Dog Films, Salter Street Films and VIF 2
results.brief_description: Michael Moore’s 2002 documentary came in the wake of the burgeoning fame and infamy that the social and media commentator, agent provocateur, satirist and political activist garnered with his television series, “The Awful truth” and publications including “Stupid white men”. In this work Moore addresses the problem of violence in America, focusing on gun culture, the prevalence of gun ownership and the sanctity of the American right to bear arms. Moore’s approach is to interview a variety of people attempting to depict a tapestry that may explain America’s relationship to guns. Among his interviewees are student survivors of the 1999 Columbine school massacre, National Rifle Association spokesperson and actor, Charlton Heston, politicians, police and various gun enthusiasts. Moore tries to dispel myths that are propagated as an explanation as to why American society is so at war with itself - its bloody history, the volume of guns amid the population, violence in the media, American’s preponderance for violent video games and films. Moore questions these theories by focusing on other less violent countries with these same qualities. One of Moore’s strongest theories is that the scare-mongering prevalent in society, broadcast through the media, and the popularity of reality TV shows, such as “COPS”, promotes the notion that danger is omnipresent to the individual and must be countered. Winner of Best Documentary at the 2003 Academy Awards, Moore’s acceptance speech earned him even greater notoriety when he criticised US President Bush and the war on Iraq.

results.title: Bowl Turning
results.brief_description: This video shows how to use gouges and flat tools, how to slow down the lathe to see exactly what happens when a tool cuts well, how to grind and sharpen the various turning tools and how to handle special challenges, like thin-wall, bark edge and end-grain bowls.

results.title: Bow and arrow
results.creator_credit: William Pettigrew, Barrie Howells, Desmond Dew, Marrin Canell and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The bow and arrow has been described as a “royal instrument of sport” and a “lethal instrument of war”. This film presents a short history of a versatile tool and describes its functions through the ages: from the days of the great conqueror Genghis Khan who over ran China with this weapon, to the modern Olympics. (Award: American Film Festival)

results.title: Botticelli: visions of beauty and violence
results.brief_description: Sandro Botticelli was one of the most popular and sought after artists of the Renaissance, renowned for his religious and mythological subjects and the beauty and sensuality of his painting. Working almost exclusively out of Florence, except for a stint in Rome to paint frescos for the Sistine Chapel, the bulk of his output was commissioned work for wealthy patrons such as the powerful Medici family. His friend and benefactor, Lorenzo di Pierfrancesco de’ Medici, commissioned Botticelli to provide illustrations for a copy of what has been viewed as the greatest ever work of Italian literature - Dante Alighieri’s Divine Comedy. Given complete artistic control over the project, Botticelli worked on the drawings between 1480 and 1495, and although they remain unfinished, they are viewed as some of the most enduring examples of his stylistic virtuosity. Working closely with Dante’s text, he painstakingly created illustrations for each section of the poem on fine goatskin parchment, expertly creating a visual interpretation of the poet’s epic passage through Hell, Purgatory and Paradise. A selection of art experts discuss the spiritual and political content, historical background and artistic execution of this work, and speculate on what drove this “explorer of beauty” to produce such a unique and animated accompaniment to Dante’s written account of the journey of the soul.

results.title: Bootmen [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dein Perry, Hilary Linstead and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Loosely based on director Dein Perry’s early life as a dancer, “Bootmen” is the story of two brothers - Sean (Adam Garcia) and Mitchell (Sam Worthington) - working in a steel mill in the industrial city of Newcastle. Both dream of one day escaping from the mill, Sean as a tap dancer in Sydney and Mitchell purchasing a tow truck to get out of the only life their stern father has ever known. Tension arrises between the brothers when Sean quits the mill to go to Sydney to study with a well known dance troupe and Mitchell moves in on Sean’s woman, Linda (Sophie Lee), both brothers finding themselves in love with her. “Bootmen” is a feel-good movie that is similar in genre to “Strictly Ballroom” and “The Full Monty”, a touching and sweet film with wonderful tap dancing sequences. Cast also includes William Zappa, Richard Carter and Susie Porter.

results.title: Boomer
results.creator_credit: Dale Phillips, Michael Scott, Tom Radford and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: For some of us home and work are not in the same place. Well paid as a boiler-maker, Gary Honig must often leave home to exercise his highly specialised skill. Sometimes, his wife and two daughters accompany him in their trailer but more often they remain behind in their home in Stony Creek, Alberta. The film describes how one family copes, combining family life, and work in the increasingly industrialised West.

results.title: Boolean procedure
results.creator_credit: Michael Coulson, Nicola Bruce and Muscle Films
results.brief_description: The introduction of Micro-technology has brought about change and crisis, which will alter our value systems and the way we spend our time. Through a bizarre mutation of live action and exciting graphic animation, the film makes us passengers in a world of artificial voices, plastic sound and faceless people. This film was shown at the Melbourne Film Festival, 1981.
